p: With the outbreak of COVID-19 and reduced fossil fuel use, for the first time, we see that a crisis has been manifested in CO2 measurements. Recent data show a 10% reduction in CO2 emissions from fossil fuels, which will undoubtedly bend the curve, which is the highest rate of emissions reduction since World War II. Carbon emissions fell 1.4% for the first time during the 2008 financial crisis,40 but emissions in 2020 are expected to decrease by approximately 5% (2.5 billion). The trends of changes in global CO2 emissions growth in 2000–2009, 2010–2018, and 2019–2020 were + 3, + 0.9, and + 0.6%, respectively.
